- **New York (Second District) — overall economic activity declined slightly; manufacturing held steady/little changed**
  - **Overall economic activity:** Economic activity in the Second District “continued to decline slightly.” [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > New York, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **Manufacturing conditions in the same period:** Manufacturing activity “was little changed after a summer uptick” / “held steady after a summer uptick.” [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Manufacturing and Distribution, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > New York, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **How manufacturing was characterized (drivers/details):**
    - New orders were down and shipments were mostly unchanged. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Manufacturing and Distribution, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Some manufacturers (electrical equipment, machinery, instruments) noted improving sales. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Manufacturing and Distribution, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Tariff-related uncertainty weighed on manufacturers via elevated input prices and difficulty procuring equipment/materials; one upstate keg manufacturer temporarily ceased production due to high steel prices. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Manufacturing and Distribution, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Some contacts reported overseas demand for U.S.-manufactured goods had dropped due to shifting international trade dynamics. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Manufacturing and Distribution, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Supply availability worsened though delivery times were little changed; inventories continued to shrink; capital spending plans were soft. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Manufacturing and Distribution, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **Kansas City (Tenth District) — overall economic activity fell slightly; manufacturing increased slightly**
  - **Overall economic activity:** Economic activity in the Tenth District “fell slightly,” with softening across several sectors. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Summary of Economic Activity, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > Kansas City, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **Manufacturing conditions in the same period:** Manufacturing activity “increased slightly over the past few weeks,” driven by clearer market expectations from tariffs. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Manufacturing and Other Business Activity, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **How manufacturing was characterized (drivers/details):**
    - High input costs remained a significant burden, though one firm said raw material costs moved from a “boil to a simmer,” with firms “no longer scrambling to contain every shock.” [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Manufacturing and Other Business Activity, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Higher-capitalized firms with less foreign import exposure expanded market share, and the cost advantage of lower-priced foreign goods “eroded slightly,” helping some domestic manufacturers gain share. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Manufacturing and Other Business Activity, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **Minneapolis District — overall economic activity contracted slightly; manufacturing was flat**
  - **Overall economic activity:** District economic activity “contracted slightly.” [Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > Minneapolis, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **Manufacturing conditions in the same period:** “Manufacturing… [was] flat.” [Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > Minneapolis, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **How manufacturing was characterized (drivers/details, from the District manufacturing section):**
    - Manufacturing activity was “flat on balance since the last report.” [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Roughly equal numbers of contacts reported decreased vs. increased orders in September (from the prior month). [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - A regional index indicated activity decreased in Minnesota and South Dakota in September (from the prior month) and increased in North Dakota. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Metal fabricators and parts producers reported a slowdown in orders, while home furnishings contacts were more mixed. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **San Francisco (Twelfth District) — overall economic activity edged down slightly; manufacturing remained stable**
  - **Overall economic activity:** Economic activity “edged down slightly.” [Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > San Francisco, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **Manufacturing conditions in the same period:** “Manufacturing… activity remained stable” (national highlight) and “manufacturing activity remained largely stable in recent weeks” (District detail). [Source: National Summary > Highlights by Federal Reserve District > San Francisco, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
  - **How manufacturing was characterized (drivers/details):**
    - Demand for automated equipment continued to grow, while demand for some manufactured furniture weakened further. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Some manufacturers noted increased excess capacity. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - Materials availability was generally adequate but at higher costs (including utilities and imported semiconductor chips). [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - A Hawaii manufacturer reported higher sale prices, reduced payroll, and lower production volumes. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]
    - In automotive, higher tariff costs led to stricter criteria for pursuing investment opportunities. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Manufacturing, Date: 2026-01-09]

v1.answer:
## Income-group definitions used in the Beige Book narratives (as stated)

- The National Summary explicitly distinguishes **“lower- and middle-income households”** versus **“higher-income individuals.”** [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- The St. Louis District explicitly discusses **“low- and middle-income households,” “middle-income consumers,”** and **“upper-income households.”** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- The New York District uses **“mid- to upper-income households”** as a group associated with spending resilience. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- The Kansas City District does not define a full set of income tiers but explicitly references **“lower income households”** as a group that “need[s] to be more selective.” [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

## What spending patterns were reported for lower-income groups (and where)

- In the National Summary, **lower-income households (grouped with middle-income)** were reported to **“continued to seek discounts and promotions.”** [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In Kansas City, **lower-income households** were described as **“more selective,”** and **sales/deals/markdowns** were reported to **drive small surges in purchasing activity**, “especially purchases by lower income households.” [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, community contacts reported **rising food pantry usage among low-income households.** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  

## What spending patterns were reported for middle-income groups (and where)

- In the National Summary, **middle-income households (grouped with lower-income)** were reported to **“continued to seek discounts and promotions.”** [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, **middle-income consumers** were reported to be **“increasingly cautious”** and to have been **“using credit to maintain their spending levels.”** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, a Missouri hotel owner reported **travel demand had dipped “especially among middle-class consumers,”** describing a “middle-class recession” affecting select-service hotels. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, community contacts reported **rising food pantry usage among middle-income households**, alongside **growing reliance on “buy now, pay later” services** and **elevated credit card delinquency rates.** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  

## What spending patterns were reported for higher-income / upper-income groups (and where)

- In the National Summary, **“spending by higher-income individuals on luxury travel and accommodation was reportedly strong.”** [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, **upper-income households** (and corporate clients) were reported to **continue to spend on “travel, events, and luxury services.”** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In New York (Second District), **consumer spending increased modestly**, “in part due to the resilience of **mid- to upper-income households**.” [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

## Explicit differences between income groups (directional contrasts stated in the evidence)

- The National Summary contrasts **discount-seeking among lower- and middle-income households** with **strong luxury travel/accommodation spending by higher-income individuals.** [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- St. Louis contrasts **continued travel/events/luxury services spending by upper-income households** with **increasing caution among middle-income consumers**, who were using credit to maintain spending. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- St. Louis also provides a services-sector example of this gap: **travel demand dipping especially among middle-class consumers** (select-service hotels), while **upper-income households continued spending on travel and luxury services.** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

## Drivers/causes cited for lower-income spending patterns (cause → observed pattern)

- **Rising prices** were cited in the National Summary as a reason **lower- and middle-income households sought discounts and promotions** (mechanism: higher prices → greater value-seeking behavior). [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- **Elevated economic uncertainty** was also cited in the National Summary in connection with **lower- and middle-income households seeking discounts and promotions** (mechanism: uncertainty → heightened caution/value-seeking). [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In Kansas City, **heightened price sensitivity** was reported to make **household consumption more volatile**, and **sales/deals/markdowns drove small surges**, “especially” for **lower income households** (mechanism: price sensitivity → purchases respond more to promotions). [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, community contacts reported **rising food pantry usage among low-income households** (the text reports the condition but does not explicitly state a cause for the increase). [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  

## Drivers/causes cited for middle-income spending patterns (cause → observed pattern)

- In the National Summary, **rising prices** and **elevated economic uncertainty** were cited alongside **lower- and middle-income households seeking discounts and promotions** (mechanism: prices/uncertainty → discount seeking). [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In St. Louis, **middle-income consumers** were described as **using credit to maintain spending levels** while becoming **increasingly cautious** (mechanism implied in text: maintaining spending via credit coincides with growing caution; the evidence does not explicitly claim credit use *caused* the caution). [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- St. Louis also reports **growing reliance on “buy now, pay later”** and **elevated credit card delinquency rates** in the same consumer-spending discussion (these are stated conditions; the evidence does not explicitly attribute them to specific drivers like rates, wages, or savings depletion). [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  

## Drivers/causes cited for higher-income spending patterns (cause → observed pattern)

- The evidence **does not explicitly identify root causes** (e.g., wealth effects, asset prices, interest income, credit availability) for higher-/upper-income strength; it only reports the pattern that **higher-income/upper-income households continued strong spending on luxury travel/services** and that **mid- to upper-income resilience contributed to modest spending increases** in New York. [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

## District/sector context tied to these patterns

- **National Summary (all Districts):** overall consumer spending “inched down,” with higher-income strength specifically in **luxury travel and accommodation** and lower-/middle-income **discount and promotion seeking.** [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- **St. Louis District:** travel/events/luxury services remained supported by **upper-income households and corporate clients**, while **middle-class consumers** were weaker in select-service hotels; reports also cite **food pantry usage**, **BNPL reliance**, and **elevated card delinquencies.** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- **Kansas City District:** consumer spending **declined slightly**; household consumption was more volatile due to **heightened price sensitivity**; promotions drove surges, especially for **lower income households**. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- **New York (Second District):** consumer spending **increased modestly**, attributed in part to **mid- to upper-income household resilience.** [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  

## Net synthesis (cause → effect narrative, without adding unsupported causation)

- Across narratives, **rising prices and heightened price sensitivity** are repeatedly linked to **greater selectivity and discount/promotion seeking among lower- and middle-income households**, producing **more promotion-driven/volatile purchasing patterns** (National Summary; Kansas City). [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- In contrast, **higher-/upper-income households** were described as **continuing to spend on travel, events, and luxury services**, with the National Summary specifically reporting **strong luxury travel and accommodation** spending by higher-income individuals (pattern difference: value-seeking vs luxury/services resilience). [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- The middle of the distribution appears more strained in some service segments: St. Louis reports **middle-income consumers becoming increasingly cautious** and that **middle-class travel demand dipped**, while also reporting **credit use to maintain spending** and **rising food pantry usage** and **delinquencies**—conditions consistent with tighter household budgets, though the document does not explicitly state a single causal root (e.g., wages, rates, depleted savings) for these developments. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  
- Regionally, New York reports **modest spending growth partly due to mid- to upper-income resilience**, suggesting the composition of spending by income group can shift aggregate outcomes even when broader activity is soft. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Summary of Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]  

### Evidence gaps (explicitly not found in the provided text)
- The evidence provided does **not** explicitly define “discretionary vs essential spenders” as named income-group categories. [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

Demand from domestic consumers for leisure and hospitality was **largely unchanged overall**, but **varied by District and by category (travel, hotels, restaurants, entertainment)**. [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

## Supporting details (by District/category)

- **National (overall):** Demand for leisure and hospitality services by **domestic consumers was largely unchanged** over the reporting period. [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **Chicago District (leisure & hospitality mix):** Leisure and hospitality sales were **mixed**, with **softness in travel-related categories (airlines and hotels)** but **increased spending at restaurants** (fast food, fast casual, and family dining). [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **Dallas District (weakness, but domestic travel strength in airlines):** Leisure and hospitality **exhibited weakness** within nonfinancial services overall, but **airlines reported broad-based increases in passenger demand** and specifically highlighted **domestic travel as a source of strength**. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas > Nonfinancial Services, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **San Francisco District (divergence within leisure/hospitality):** Consumer demand at **entertainment venues and some quick service restaurants continued to grow**, partly due to **successful marketing campaigns and diversified offerings**, while **demand for hospitality and travel services declined further** and **lower sales at full-service restaurants** led to some closures in the Pacific Northwest. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **Atlanta District (travel and lodging softening):** **Leisure travel activity declined slightly**, **domestic travel booking windows shortened**, and **hotel occupancy levels continued to trend downward** on net; **business and group travel were flat**, while **cruising was the strongest segment** with **solid passenger volumes**. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **New York District (domestic tourism up; hotel demand edging up):** **Domestic tourism continued to grow in New York City**, while **demand for hotel rooms continued to edge up** during the busy September season, nearing levels last seen in 2019. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

- **St. Louis District (softening concentrated among middle-income; some leisure venues weaker):** A hotel owner in Missouri reported **travel demand had dipped** in recent months, **especially among middle-class consumers**, and additional contacts reported **slow business** (hotel/restaurant in Mississippi), **fewer room rentals and gatherings** (event center in Northwest Arkansas), and **lower sales** at youth-focused gaming facilities. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

## Context/drivers mentioned in the evidence (where specified)
- **Category mix explains “unchanged overall” demand:** Some areas saw **declines in lodging/travel** but **strength in certain restaurant/entertainment segments**. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]
- **Income-based divergence:** Spending by **higher-income individuals on luxury travel and accommodation was reportedly strong**, while some District reporting (St. Louis) described weaker travel demand particularly among **middle-class consumers**. [Source: Section: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09; Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]
- **Marketing/offerings supported entertainment demand in the West:** Growth at entertainment venues and some quick service restaurants was attributed partially to **successful marketing campaigns and diversified offerings**. [Source: Section: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, Document: BeigeBook_20251015, Date: 2026-01-09]

Demand from domestic consumers for leisure and hospitality was **largely unchanged overall**, with **District-level reports showing a mixed picture** (some categories and regions increasing, others declining) during the Beige Book reporting period. [Source: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]

## Supporting details (scope/definition, direction, magnitude, geography, and context)

### 1) Scope/definition used for “leisure and hospitality” in the provided Beige Book evidence
In the evidence, “leisure and hospitality” demand is discussed through **travel and lodging (airlines, hotels, hotel rooms, occupancy, room rates), restaurants (quick service and full-service), entertainment/attractions (entertainment venues, Broadway shows, cultural attractions), events/gatherings (event centers, room rentals), and gaming/entertainment facilities**. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas > Nonfinancial Services, 2026-01-09]

### 2) National/overall change in domestic consumer demand
The National Summary states that **“demand for leisure and hospitality services by domestic consumers was largely unchanged”** over the reporting period. [Source: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, 2026-01-09]

### 3) District-level changes (direction and magnitude/pace qualifiers)

**San Francisco District (mixed, with declines in hospitality/travel but growth in some dining/entertainment):**
- **Consumer demand at entertainment venues and some quick service restaurants “continued to grow,”** with growth partially attributed to “successful marketing campaigns and diversified offerings.” [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, 2026-01-09]
- At the same time, **demand for “hospitality and travel services declined further,”** and **lower sales at full-service restaurants** contributed to **some business closures in the Pacific Northwest**. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, 2026-01-09]

**Chicago District (mixed):**
- **“Leisure and hospitality sales were mixed,”** with **“softness in some travel-related categories, including airlines and hotels,”** but **“increased spending at restaurants”** (fast food, fast casual, and family dining). [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]

**Dallas District (weakness overall in leisure & hospitality, but domestic travel strength in airlines):**
- Dallas reported **“leisure and hospitality exhibited weakness”** while overall nonfinancial services **“contracted slightly.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas > Nonfinancial Services, 2026-01-09]
- In contrast, **airlines reported “broad-based increases in passenger demand,”** explicitly noting **“domestic travel as a source of strength.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas > Nonfinancial Services, 2026-01-09]

**Atlanta District (slight decline in leisure travel; hotel occupancy trending down; cruising strong):**
- **“Leisure travel activity declined slightly since the previous report,”** and **hotel occupancy “continued to trend downward, on net.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]
- **Business and group travel were flat**, while **cruising “remained the strongest segment,”** with ports reporting **“solid passenger volumes.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]
- Domestic-consumer-related context: **“domestic travel booking windows shortened.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]

**New York District (domestic tourism growth; busy season context; high prices):**
- **“Domestic tourism continued to grow in New York City.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, 2026-01-09]
- **Demand for hotel rooms “continued to edge up during the busy September season,”** with **room rates “remaining exceptionally high.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, 2026-01-09]
- Related leisure activity: **Broadway attendance “remained solid,”** while other cultural attractions were **“flat to down slightly.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, 2026-01-09]

**St. Louis District (softening/dips, especially among middle-class consumers):**
- The District reported **consumer spending “has slightly declined,”** while **a hotel owner in Missouri said travel demand “had dipped in the past few months,” especially among middle-class consumers**, affecting select-service hotels. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]
- Additional leisure/hospitality weakness cited: a **hotel and restaurant in Mississippi reported slow business in August and September**, an **event center in Northwest Arkansas reported fewer room rentals and gatherings**, and **youth-focused gaming facilities reported lower sales**. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]
- The same section notes a split by income: **upper-income households and corporate clients continued to spend on travel, events, and luxury services,** while **middle-income consumers were increasingly cautious**. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]

### 4) Contextual qualifiers affecting interpretation
- **Seasonality:** New York City hotel room demand increased **“during the busy September season.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, 2026-01-09]
- **Pricing:** New York City **room rates were “exceptionally high”** alongside rising hotel-room demand. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Services, 2026-01-09]
- **Marketing/product mix:** San Francisco District growth in entertainment venues and some quick service restaurants was linked partly to **“successful marketing campaigns and diversified offerings.”** [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco > Retail Trade and Services, 2026-01-09]
- **Consumer income mix/financial stress:** St. Louis reported continued spending by **upper-income households**, but increased caution among **middle-income consumers**, including reliance on credit and related indicators (e.g., “buy now, pay later” and elevated delinquency rates), which accompanied reports of weaker travel/hospitality demand in some areas. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]
- **Labor availability (industry operating context):** In New York, some businesses in **leisure and hospitality reported difficulty finding workers due to shifts in immigration policy**, which could affect capacity, though the evidence does not directly tie this to demand changes. [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of New York > Labor Markets, 2026-01-09]

### 5) Reporting period (as stated in the evidence)
The National Summary describes conditions **“since the previous report”** and refers to changes occurring **“over the reporting period.”** [Source: National Summary > Overall Economic Activity, 2026-01-09]  
District narratives also use “over the reporting period” and, in Atlanta’s case, explicitly compare to “the previous report.” [Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09; Source: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta > Consumer Spending, 2026-01-09]

The evidence does not provide a single formal Beige Book definition statement for “leisure and hospitality”; the scope above is inferred strictly from the categories explicitly discussed (hotels, restaurants, travel, entertainment, events, etc.).
